Title: Which functional form best describes episodic forgetting trajectories across a 6-day retention interval?
Hypothesis: Exploratory analysis comparing 5 candidate models (Linear, Quadratic, Logarithmic, Linear+Logarithmic, Quadratic+Logarithmic). No directional prediction. Expected: best model Akaike weight > 0.30.
Data_Required: Source: results/ch5/5.2.1/data/step00_irt_input.csv (400 rows, all What/Where/When items). TSVR mapping: results/ch5/5.2.1/data/step00_tsvr_mapping.csv (actual hours since encoding). Sample: N=100 participants x 4 tests = 400 observations. Transformations: Days = TSVR_hours/24, Days_squared, log_Days_plus1.
Analysis_Specification: (1) IRT Pass 1 calibration with single omnibus "All" factor on all items using GRM, p1_med prior. (2) Item purification (Decision D039): exclude items with |b| > 3.0 OR a < 0.4. (3) IRT Pass 2 re-calibration on purified items. (4) Merge theta with TSVR, create time transformations. (5) Fit 5 LMMs with REML=False: Linear, Quadratic, Logarithmic, Lin+Log, Quad+Log; all with random slopes by UID. (6) Model selection via AIC, compute Akaike weights. (7) Prepare plot data: observed means + model predictions, theta and probability scales (Decision D069).
Expected_Output: data/step01_theta_scores.csv; data/step02_purified_items.csv (40-60 items); data/step03_theta_scores.csv (final); data/step04_lmm_input.csv (400 rows); results/step05_model_comparison.csv (5 models); data/step06_best_model.pkl; results/step06_aic_comparison.csv; plots/step07_functional_form_theta_data.csv; plots/step07_functional_form_probability_data.csv
Success_Criteria: IRT convergence: theta in [-4,4], SE in [0.1,1.5]. Purification: 30-70% retention. LMM: all 5 models converge, AIC finite. Akaike weights sum to 1.0 +/- 0.01. Best model weight > 0.30. Plot data: probability in [0,1], no NaN.

Title: Do episodic memory data support a two-phase model with rapid initial decline (Day 0-1) followed by slower decay (Day 1-6)?
Hypothesis: Forgetting exhibits two distinct phases: rapid initial decline (Day 0-1) followed by slower decay (Day 1-6). Evidence from three tests: (1) significant quadratic term (p < 0.003333 Bonferroni), (2) piecewise model AIC < continuous AIC by > 2, (3) Late/Early slope ratio < 0.5.
Data_Required: Source: results/ch5/5.1.1/data/step03_theta_scores.csv (theta scores), results/ch5/5.1.1/data/step00_tsvr_mapping.csv (TSVR). Best continuous model from RQ 5.1.1. Sample: N=100 participants, 400 observations. Variables: theta, TSVR_hours, Segment (Early: 0-48h, Late: 48-240h), Days_within. Time transformations: Time, Time^2, Time_log.
Analysis_Specification: (0) Load theta and best continuous model from RQ 5.1.1. (1) Create time transformations with 48h cutoff. (2) Test 1: Fit quadratic model theta ~ Time + Time^2 + (Time | UID); test Time^2 p < 0.003333 Bonferroni. (3) Test 2: Fit piecewise model theta ~ Days_within x Segment; compare AIC to continuous. (4) Validate LMM assumptions (6 checks). (5) Test 3: Extract Early/Late slopes, compute ratio; test interaction p-value. (6) Prepare two-panel plot data.
Expected_Output: results/step02_quadratic_model_summary.txt; data/step02_quadratic_predictions.csv; results/step03_piecewise_model_summary.txt (AIC comparison); data/step03_piecewise_predictions.csv; results/step04_assumption_validation_report.txt; results/step05_slope_comparison.csv (4 rows: Early, Late, Ratio, Interaction_p); plots/step06_piecewise_comparison_data.csv
Success_Criteria: Convergence: both models converge. Retention >= 95%. Bonferroni alpha = 0.003333. At least 2/3 tests support two-phase: Time^2 significant, ΔAIC < -2, slope ratio < 0.5. Assumption validation complete. Plot data exists with correct structure.

Title: Do older adults show lower baseline episodic memory (intercept) and/or faster forgetting (steeper slope) compared to younger adults?
Hypothesis: Age will negatively predict both intercept (baseline memory at Day 0) and slope (forgetting rate), consistent with hippocampal aging effects. Primary: Age_c on intercept significant (p < 0.0167 Bonferroni). Secondary: Age_c x log(Time+1) interaction significant.
Data_Required: Source: results/ch5/5.1.1/data/step03_theta_scores.csv (IRT theta), results/ch5/5.1.1/data/step00_tsvr_mapping.csv (TSVR), data/cache/dfData.csv (Age variable). Sample: N=100 participants x 4 tests = 400 observations. Variables: theta, TSVR_hours, age (20-70 years). Transformations: Age_c (grand-mean centered), Time, Time_log.
Analysis_Specification: (0) Merge theta from RQ 5.1.1 with TSVR and Age. (1) Grand-mean center Age (Age_c), verify mean ~ 0. (2) Fit LMM: theta ~ (Time + Time_log) x Age_c + (Time | UID), REML=False. (3) Extract Age_c, Time:Age_c, Time_log:Age_c; apply Bonferroni alpha = 0.0167. Report dual p-values (Decision D068). (4) Compute effect size at Day 6 for average age vs age+1SD. (5) Create age tertiles (Young/Middle/Older), aggregate means for plot.
Expected_Output: data/step00_lmm_input_raw.csv (400 rows, 7 cols); data/step01_lmm_input_prepared.csv (10 cols); data/step02_lmm_model.pkl; results/step02_lmm_summary.txt; data/step02_fixed_effects.csv (6 terms); data/step03_age_effects.csv (3 rows, dual p-values); data/step04_effect_size.csv; plots/step05_age_tertile_plot_data.csv (12 rows)
Success_Criteria: Convergence: model.converged=True. All 400 observations present. Age_c mean ~ 0. 6 fixed effect terms present. Dual p-values (Decision D068). Random variances positive. Plot data: 12 rows (3 tertiles x 4 timepoints), CI_upper > CI_lower.

Title: What proportion of variance in forgetting rate (slopes) is between-person (stable individual differences) vs within-person (measurement error)?
Hypothesis: Substantial between-person variance exists in forgetting rate (ICC for slopes > 0.40), indicating forgetting rate is a stable, trait-like individual difference. Secondary: negative intercept-slope correlation (high performers maintain advantage).
Data_Required: DERIVED from RQ 5.1.1: results/ch5/5.1.1/data/step06_best_model.pkl (saved LMM model), results/ch5/5.1.1/data/step03_theta_scores.csv, results/ch5/5.1.1/data/step04_lmm_input.csv. Sample: N=100 participants, all 4 tests. "All" factor items. No new IRT calibration required.
Analysis_Specification: (1) Load RQ 5.1.1 model with convergence validation. (2) Extract variance components: var_intercept, var_slope, cov_int_slope, var_residual from cov_re. (3) Compute ICC estimates: ICC_intercept, ICC_slope_simple, ICC_slope_conditional at Day 6. Interpret: <0.20=Low, 0.20-0.40=Moderate, >=0.40=Substantial. (4) Extract individual random effects for 100 participants. (5) Test intercept-slope correlation with Decision D068 dual p-values (Bonferroni alpha=0.0033). Create histogram and Q-Q plot.
Expected_Output: data/step01_model_metadata.yaml; data/step02_variance_components.csv (5 components); data/step03_icc_estimates.csv (3 ICC types); results/step03_icc_summary.txt; data/step04_random_effects.csv (100 rows, REQUIRED for RQ 5.1.5); results/step04_random_slopes_descriptives.txt; data/step05_intercept_slope_correlation.csv (5 statistics); plots/step05_random_slopes_histogram.png; plots/step05_random_slopes_qqplot.png
Success_Criteria: Model converged=True. Variance components positive. ICC in [0,1]. 100 participants extracted, no NaN. Correlation test D068-compliant (both p_uncorrected & p_bonferroni). PNG files > 10KB. RQ 5.1.1 dependency circuit breaker active.

Title: Can participants be grouped into latent classes based on their forgetting trajectories (intercepts and slopes)?
Hypothesis: Exploratory. Expected 2-3 profiles: (1) High baseline, slow forgetting; (2) Average baseline, average forgetting; (3) Low baseline, fast forgetting. Number determined by BIC model selection.
Data_Required: DERIVED from RQ 5.1.4: results/ch5/5.1.4/data/step04_random_effects.csv (Total_Intercept, Total_Slope per UID). Theta scores from RQ 5.1.1 for trajectory plotting. TSVR mapping from RQ 5.1.1. Sample: N=100 participants, 2 clustering variables.
Analysis_Specification: (1) Load random effects from RQ 5.1.4 (Total_Intercept, Total_Slope). (2) Standardize to z-scores (mean=0, SD=1). (3) Test K=1 to K=6 using K-means; compute inertia and BIC; select optimal K as BIC minimum. (4) Fit final K-means (random_state=42, n_init=50); extract cluster assignments and centers. (5) Characterize clusters: mean intercept/slope per cluster, assign interpretive labels. (6) Scatter plot colored by cluster with centers and reference lines.
Expected_Output: data/step00_random_effects_from_rq514.csv; data/step01_standardized_features.csv; results/step02_cluster_selection.csv (K=1-6: inertia, BIC); results/step03_optimal_k.txt; data/step04_cluster_assignments.csv (100 rows: UID, cluster); results/step04_cluster_centers.csv (K rows); results/step05_cluster_characterization.txt; plots/step06_cluster_scatter.png
Success_Criteria: Random effects loaded (100 participants). Standardization correct (mean~0, SD~1). BIC minimum identified. Cluster sizes balanced (no cluster < 10%). Cluster centers interpretable. Plot shows clear separation. Replicates with seed=42.

Title: Do easier items (lower difficulty) show faster forgetting than harder items, consistent with initial strength predicting decay rate?
Hypothesis: Exploratory. Competing predictions: (1) Easier items = weaker encoding -> faster forgetting (positive interaction), (2) Easier items = ceiling effects -> slower apparent forgetting (negative interaction), (3) No interaction (difficulty affects intercept only).
Data_Required: Item parameters from RQ 5.2.1: results/ch5/5.2.1/data/step03_item_parameters.csv. Raw response data: data/cache/dfData.csv. TSVR mapping from RQ 5.2.1. Structure: Item-level responses (UID x Test x Item), crossed random effects.
Analysis_Specification: (1) Load item parameters (difficulty from IRT) and raw responses in long format. (2) Merge item difficulty into response-level data. (3) Grand-mean center Difficulty (Difficulty_c). (4) Fit cross-classified LMM: Response ~ Time x Difficulty_c + (Time | UID) + (1 | Item). Use pymer4 for crossed random effects. (5) Extract Time x Difficulty_c interaction; test significance at Bonferroni alpha = 0.0033. (6) Plot easy (-1SD) vs hard (+1SD) item trajectories.
Expected_Output: data/step00_item_difficulty.csv; data/step01_response_level_data.csv (long format); data/step02_merged_data.csv; results/step03_lmm_model_summary.txt; results/step03_difficulty_interaction.csv (coefficient, SE, z, p); plots/step04_difficulty_trajectories.png
Success_Criteria: pymer4 model converged. Item difficulty merged correctly. Difficulty_c centered (mean~0). Interaction term extracted. Interpretation matches coefficient sign. Plot shows divergence (if significant) or parallelism. Replicates.

Title: Are there domain-specific differences in the rate and pattern of episodic forgetting over 6 days for What, Where, and When memory components?
Hypothesis: Object identity (What) may be more resilient than spatial (Where) or temporal (When) memory, based on dual-process theory. Expected: significant Domain x Time interaction showing What with slower forgetting than Where and When.
Data_Required: Source: data/cache/dfData.csv (100 participants x 4 tests). Variables: UID, TEST, TSVR (hours), TQ_* items. Dichotomization: TQ < 1 -> 0, >= 1 -> 1. Domain items: What (*-N-*) = 29, Where (*-L-*/*-U-*/*-D-*) = 50, When (*-O-*) = 26. Time: TSVR_hours. Sample: N=100, 400 composite observations.
Analysis_Specification: (0) Extract VR data, dichotomize, create Q-matrix (what/where/when factors). (1) IRT Pass 1: 3-dimensional GRM, correlated factors. (2) Purify items: Decision D039 (a >= 0.4, |b| <= 3.0). (3) IRT Pass 2 on purified items. (4) Merge theta with TSVR, reshape wide->long (1200 rows). (5) Fit 5 LMMs with Domain x Time; select best via AIC. (6) Post-hoc contrasts: where-what, when-what, Bonferroni alpha=0.0167. Report dual p-values (Decision D068). (7) Prepare trajectory data (Decision D069).
Expected_Output: data/step00_irt_input.csv; data/step00_q_matrix.csv; data/step02_purified_items.csv (70 items); data/step03_theta_scores.csv (400 rows); data/step04_lmm_input.csv (1200 rows); results/step05_lmm_model_comparison.csv; data/step05_lmm_fitted_model.pkl; results/step06_post_hoc_contrasts.csv; results/step06_effect_sizes.csv; plots/step07_trajectory_theta_data.csv; plots/step07_trajectory_probability_data.csv
Success_Criteria: IRT convergence confirmed. Purification: >= 10 items per domain. LMM best model converged. 1200 observations in merged data. Post-hoc: p_bonferroni >= p_uncorrected. Plot data: 12 rows (3 domains x 4 tests), probability in [0,1].

Title: Do memory domains (What/Where/When) show different rates of forgetting during the early consolidation window (Day 0->1) versus later decay (Day 1->6)?
Hypothesis: Sleep-dependent consolidation (Day 0->1) may benefit spatial memory (Where) more than semantic (What). Secondary: 3-way interaction (Days_within x Segment x Domain) will be significant.
Data_Required: DERIVED from RQ 5.2.1: results/ch5/5.2.1/data/step04_lmm_input.csv, results/ch5/5.2.1/data/step03_item_parameters.csv. Variables: composite_ID, UID, test, TSVR_hours, domain, theta, se. Sample: N=100, 1200 observations. Segments: Early (tests 0-1), Late (tests 3-6). Days_within recentered.
Analysis_Specification: (0) Load RQ 5.2.1 theta, create Segment and Days_within. (1) Fit piecewise LMM: theta ~ Days_within x Segment x domain + (1 + Days_within | UID), REML=False. (2) Extract 6 segment-domain slopes via linear combinations. (3) Compute 6 planned contrasts with Bonferroni alpha=0.0083. Report dual p-values (Decision D068). Compute Cohen's f^2. (4) Consolidation benefit index per domain. (5) Prepare piecewise plot data (theta and probability scales).
Expected_Output: data/step00_piecewise_lmm_input.csv (1200 rows, 9 cols); data/step01_piecewise_lmm_model.pkl; results/step01_piecewise_lmm_summary.txt; results/step02_segment_domain_slopes.csv (6 rows); results/step03_planned_contrasts.csv (6 rows); results/step03_effect_sizes.csv; results/step04_consolidation_benefit.csv (3 rows); plots/step05_piecewise_theta_data.csv; plots/step05_piecewise_probability_data.csv
Success_Criteria: Model converged, 7 fixed effects estimated. 6 segment-domain slopes with valid SE/CI. 6 contrasts with dual p-values (Decision D068). 3 domains with consolidation benefit ranks. Plot data: 12 rows, correct segment assignments.

Title: Does the effect of age on forgetting rate vary by memory domain (What, Where, When)?
Hypothesis: Age x Time effects will be strongest for spatial (Where) and temporal (When) domains relying on hippocampal binding, compared to object identity (What) relying on perirhinal cortex. 3-way Age x Domain x Time interaction significant at Bonferroni alpha=0.025.
Data_Required: DERIVED from RQ 5.2.1: results/ch5/5.2.1/data/step03_theta_scores.csv (1200 rows), results/ch5/5.2.1/data/step00_tsvr_mapping.csv (400 rows). Age from data/cache/dfData.csv. Variables: theta, TSVR_hours, age, domain. Sample: N=100, 1200 observations. Transformations: Age_c (centered), log_TSVR.
Analysis_Specification: (0) Load RQ 5.2.1 theta + Age. (1) Merge, center Age, create log_TSVR. (2) Fit LMM: theta ~ TSVR_hours + log_TSVR + Age_c + domain + all 2-way + 3-way interactions + (TSVR_hours | UID). (2b) Validate 7 assumptions. (2c) Model selection via LRT. (3) Extract 4 three-way terms, Bonferroni alpha=0.025. (4) Domain-specific age effects at Day 3 with Tukey HSD. (5) Plot by age tertiles.
Expected_Output: data/step00_theta_from_rq51.csv; data/step01_lmm_input.csv (1200 rows, 10 cols); data/step02_lmm_model.pkl; data/step02_fixed_effects.csv (21 terms); results/step02b_assumption_diagnostics.txt; data/step03_interaction_terms.csv (4 rows); data/step04_age_effects_by_domain.csv (3 rows); data/step04_post_hoc_contrasts.csv; plots/step05_age_effects_plot_data.csv
Success_Criteria: Model converged, 21 fixed effects. 4 three-way interaction terms present. Dual p-values (Decision D068). 3 domains with age effects. Plot data: all 3 domains x 3 tertiles x 4 tests.

Title: Do IRT theta scores and CTT mean scores yield the same conclusions about domain-specific forgetting trajectories?
Hypothesis: IRT and CTT should converge (r > 0.70 strong, r > 0.90 exceptional; Cohen's kappa > 0.60 substantial agreement), demonstrating robustness to measurement approach.
Data_Required: IRT theta from RQ 5.2.1: results/ch5/5.2.1/data/step03_theta_scores.csv. TSVR from RQ 5.2.1. Purified items from RQ 5.2.1. Raw data: data/cache/dfData.csv. Sample: N=100 x 4 tests x 3 domains = 1200 observations. CTT computed on purified item set.
Analysis_Specification: (0) Load IRT theta, TSVR, purified items; filter raw data to purified items. (1) Compute CTT mean scores per UID x test x domain. (2) Pearson correlations per domain with Holm-Bonferroni; test r > 0.70 and r > 0.90. Report dual p-values (Decision D068). (3) Fit parallel LMMs (identical formula) for IRT and CTT; simplify both if either fails convergence. (4) Validate assumptions for both. (5) Compare fixed effects: Cohen's kappa > 0.60 threshold. (6) Compare AIC/BIC. (7-8) Prepare scatterplot and trajectory data.
Expected_Output: results/step02_correlations.csv (4 rows); results/step03_irt_lmm_summary.txt; results/step03_ctt_lmm_summary.txt; results/step04_assumptions_comparison.csv; results/step05_coefficient_comparison.csv (12 cols); results/step05_agreement_metrics.csv; results/step06_model_fit_comparison.csv; plots/step07_scatterplot_data.csv (1200 rows); plots/step08_trajectory_data.csv (24 rows)
Success_Criteria: All correlations r > 0.70. Cohen's kappa > 0.60. Agreement >= 80%. Both models converge with identical structure. Output files with correct row/column counts. Dual p-values present.

Title: If we compute CTT scores using only IRT-retained items (post-purification), do conclusions differ from full-item CTT?
Hypothesis: Purified CTT will show higher correlation with IRT theta (delta_r ~ +0.02) compared to full CTT, demonstrating item purification removes measurement noise. Secondary: Purified CTT yields better LMM fit (lower AIC).
Data_Required: DERIVED from RQ 5.2.1: results/ch5/5.2.1/data/step02_purified_items.csv, results/ch5/5.2.1/data/step03_theta_scores.csv, results/ch5/5.2.1/data/step00_tsvr_mapping.csv. Raw data: data/cache/dfData.csv. Sample: N=100 x 4 tests = 400 observations. Items: Full CTT ~50, Purified CTT ~38.
Analysis_Specification: (0) Load RQ 5.2.1 outputs, verify dependency. (1) Map retained vs removed items. (2) Compute Full CTT (all items). (3) Compute Purified CTT (retained only). (4) Cronbach's alpha with bootstrap CIs. (5) Correlation analysis with Steiger's z-test, Bonferroni for 3 domains. Report dual p-values (Decision D068). (6) Z-standardize all measurements. (7) Fit parallel LMMs on z-standardized; compare AIC per Burnham & Anderson. (8) Prepare correlation and AIC comparison data.
Expected_Output: data/step01_item_mapping.csv (~50 rows); data/step02_ctt_full_scores.csv (400 rows); data/step03_ctt_purified_scores.csv (400 rows); data/step04_reliability_assessment.csv (3 rows); data/step05_correlation_analysis.csv (3 rows); data/step07_lmm_model_comparison.csv (3 rows); plots/step08_correlation_comparison_data.csv; plots/step08_aic_comparison_data.csv
Success_Criteria: Data loading verified. Item mapping: 48-52 total, 36-40 retained. CTT scores in [0,1]. Correlations with dual p-values. Z-standardization correct. All 3 LMMs converge. Plot data: 6 rows correlation, 3 rows AIC.

Title: What proportion of variance in forgetting rate is between-person vs within-person for each domain (What, Where, When)?
Hypothesis: Substantial between-person variance (ICC for slopes > 0.40) exists within each domain, with potential domain differences in ICC magnitude reflecting differential trait-like stability of forgetting.
Data_Required: DERIVED from RQ 5.2.1: best-fitting LMM model with random slopes by domain. Theta scores from results/ch5/5.2.1/data/step04_lmm_input.csv. Sample: N=100 participants, 1200 observations (3 domains). No new IRT calibration required.
Analysis_Specification: (1) Fit domain-stratified LMMs with random slopes: theta ~ Time + (Time | UID) separately for What, Where, When. (2) Extract variance components per domain: var_intercept, var_slope, cov_int_slope, var_residual. (3) Compute ICC estimates per domain: ICC_intercept, ICC_slope_simple, ICC_slope_conditional at Day 6. (4) Extract individual random effects per domain for 100 participants. (5) Test intercept-slope correlations per domain with Bonferroni alpha=0.0033. (6) Compare ICC across domains.
Expected_Output: data/step01_model_metadata_what.yaml; data/step01_model_metadata_where.yaml; data/step01_model_metadata_when.yaml; data/step02_variance_components.csv (15 rows: 5 components x 3 domains); data/step03_icc_estimates.csv (9 rows: 3 ICC x 3 domains); data/step04_random_effects.csv (300 rows: 100 UID x 3 domains); data/step05_domain_icc_comparison.csv; plots/step06_domain_icc_barplot.png
Success_Criteria: All 3 domain models converge. Variance components positive. ICC in [0,1]. 300 random effects extracted. Dual p-values for correlations. Domain comparison interpretable.

Title: Can participants be grouped into latent classes based on domain-specific forgetting trajectories (What/Where/When intercepts and slopes)?
Hypothesis: Exploratory. Expected 2-4 profiles based on 6 clustering variables (intercept + slope for each domain). Profiles may show domain-selective impairment (e.g., poor spatial memory only).
Data_Required: DERIVED from RQ 5.2.6: random effects per domain (Total_Intercept_What/Where/When, Total_Slope_What/Where/When). Sample: N=100 participants, 6 clustering variables.
Analysis_Specification: (1) Load random effects from RQ 5.2.6 (6 variables per UID). (2) Standardize to z-scores. (3) Test K=1 to K=6 using K-means; compute inertia and BIC. (4) Fit final K-means with optimal K. (5) Characterize clusters by domain-specific patterns. (6) Scatter plot matrix colored by cluster.
Expected_Output: data/step00_random_effects_from_rq526.csv; data/step01_standardized_features.csv (100 x 6); results/step02_cluster_selection.csv; results/step03_optimal_k.txt; data/step04_cluster_assignments.csv; results/step04_cluster_centers.csv; results/step05_cluster_characterization.txt; plots/step06_cluster_scatter_matrix.png
Success_Criteria: Random effects loaded (100 x 6). Standardization correct. BIC minimum identified. Cluster sizes >= 10%. Domain-specific interpretations. Plot shows separation.

Title: Do easier items show faster forgetting than harder items, and does this differ by domain?
Hypothesis: Exploratory. Tests if item difficulty x time interaction differs across What/Where/When domains. Domain-specific difficulty effects may reflect different forgetting mechanisms.
Data_Required: Item parameters from RQ 5.2.1. Raw response data. TSVR mapping. Structure: Item-level responses with domain grouping. Crossed random effects (UID x Item).
Analysis_Specification: (1) Load item parameters and raw responses. (2) Merge item difficulty and domain. (3) Center Difficulty_c. (4) Fit: Response ~ Time x Difficulty_c x domain + (Time | UID) + (1 | Item). (5) Extract Time x Difficulty_c x domain interactions; Bonferroni alpha=0.0033. (6) Plot easy vs hard trajectories per domain.
Expected_Output: data/step00_item_difficulty_by_domain.csv; data/step01_response_level_data.csv; results/step03_lmm_model_summary.txt; results/step03_difficulty_domain_interaction.csv; plots/step04_difficulty_trajectories_by_domain.png
Success_Criteria: Model converged. Domain-stratified interactions extracted. Interpretation clear. Plot shows 6 lines (2 difficulty x 3 domains).

Title: Do Free Recall, Cued Recall, and Recognition paradigms exhibit different forgetting rates over 6 days?
Hypothesis: Free Recall shows steepest forgetting (requires self-initiated retrieval), followed by Cued Recall, with Recognition showing most shallow decline. Expected: significant Paradigm x Time interaction.
Data_Required: Source: RQ 5.2.1 data filtered to paradigm items. Paradigms: IFR (Item Free Recall), ICR (Item Cued Recall), IRE (Item Recognition). Exclude RFR, TCR. Sample: N=100 x 4 tests x 3 paradigms = 1200 observations. Time: TSVR_hours.
Analysis_Specification: (0) Filter to IFR/ICR/IRE items, create paradigm Q-matrix. (1) IRT Pass 1: 3-factor GRM. (2) Purify (Decision D039). (3) IRT Pass 2. (4) Merge theta with TSVR, reshape to long (paradigm factor). (5) Fit 5 LMMs with Paradigm x Time; select best via AIC. (6) Post-hoc contrasts: Cued-Free, Recognition-Free, Bonferroni alpha=0.0167. Report dual p-values (Decision D068). (7) Prepare trajectory data.
Expected_Output: data/step03_theta_scores.csv; results/step05_model_comparison.csv; results/step05_lmm_model_summary.txt; data/step05_fixed_effects.csv; results/step06_post_hoc_contrasts.csv; results/step06_effect_sizes.csv; plots/step07_trajectory_theta_data.csv; plots/step07_trajectory_probability_data.csv
Success_Criteria: IRT convergence. 40-80 items retained. LMM best model converged. 1200 observations. Post-hoc dual p-values. Plot: 12 rows, probability in [0,1].

Title: Does forgetting rate decrease monotonically from Free Recall -> Cued Recall -> Recognition?
Hypothesis: Forgetting rate follows ordered trend: Free > Cued > Recognition. Linear trend contrast significant at Bonferroni alpha=0.0033, positive coefficient indicating forgetting decreases with retrieval support.
Data_Required: DERIVED from RQ 5.3.1: results/ch5/5.3.1/data/step05_lmm_fitted_model.pkl (Log model), results/ch5/5.3.1/data/step04_lmm_input.csv. Sample: 1200 observations (100 x 4 x 3 paradigms).
Analysis_Specification: (0) Load RQ 5.3.1 LMM model, verify Log model and paradigm categories. (1) Extract marginal means at Day 3 midpoint. (2) Compute linear trend contrast: weights [-1, 0, +1] for Free/Cued/Recognition. Report dual p-values (Decision D068). Bonferroni alpha=0.0033. (3) Prepare plot data with fitted trend line.
Expected_Output: data/step00_model_loaded.txt; data/step01_marginal_means.csv (3 rows); results/step02_linear_trend_contrast.csv (1 row); results/step02_contrast_interpretation.txt; plots/step03_paradigm_forgetting_rates_data.csv (3 rows); plots/step03_contrast_annotation.txt
Success_Criteria: Model loaded, Log model confirmed. 3 marginal means in [-3,3]. Linear trend contrast with dual p-values. Plot data: 3 rows, CI_lower < CI_upper.

Title: Do retrieval paradigms (Free/Cued/Recognition) show different consolidation benefits during Day 0->1 versus later decay?
Hypothesis: Sleep-dependent consolidation (Day 0->1) may differentially benefit paradigms. Free Recall may show greatest early consolidation effect due to deeper encoding requirements.
Data_Required: DERIVED from RQ 5.3.1: results/ch5/5.3.1/data/step04_lmm_input.csv (theta by paradigm), item parameters. Sample: N=100, 1200 observations. Segments: Early (tests 0-1), Late (tests 3-6).
Analysis_Specification: (0) Load RQ 5.3.1 theta, create Segment and Days_within. (1) Fit piecewise LMM: theta ~ Days_within x Segment x paradigm + (1 + Days_within | UID). (2) Extract 6 segment-paradigm slopes. (3) Compute 6 planned contrasts with Bonferroni alpha=0.0083. Report dual p-values (Decision D068). (4) Consolidation benefit index per paradigm. (5) Prepare piecewise plot data.
Expected_Output: data/step00_piecewise_lmm_input.csv; data/step01_piecewise_lmm_model.pkl; results/step02_segment_paradigm_slopes.csv (6 rows); results/step03_planned_contrasts.csv; results/step04_consolidation_benefit.csv (3 rows); plots/step05_piecewise_theta_data.csv; plots/step05_piecewise_probability_data.csv
Success_Criteria: Model converged. 6 slopes with valid SE/CI. 6 contrasts with dual p-values. Plot data: 12 rows.

Title: Does the effect of age on forgetting rate vary by retrieval paradigm?
Hypothesis: Age x Time effects may be strongest for Free Recall (most demanding) and weakest for Recognition (familiarity-based). 3-way Age x Paradigm x Time interaction significant at Bonferroni alpha=0.025.
Data_Required: DERIVED from RQ 5.3.1: theta scores (1200 rows), TSVR mapping. Age from data/cache/dfData.csv. Sample: N=100, 1200 observations. Transformations: Age_c, log_TSVR.
Analysis_Specification: (0) Load RQ 5.3.1 theta + Age. (1) Merge, center Age, create log_TSVR. (2) Fit LMM with 3-way Age x paradigm x Time interactions + (TSVR_hours | UID). (3) Extract 4 three-way terms, Bonferroni alpha=0.025. (4) Paradigm-specific age effects at Day 3 with Tukey HSD. Report dual p-values (Decision D068). (5) Plot by age tertiles.
Expected_Output: data/step01_lmm_input.csv (1200 rows); data/step02_lmm_model.pkl; data/step03_interaction_terms.csv (4 rows); data/step04_age_effects_by_paradigm.csv (3 rows); plots/step05_age_effects_plot_data.csv
Success_Criteria: Model converged. 4 three-way terms present. Dual p-values. 3 paradigms with age effects. Plot data complete.

Title: Do IRT theta scores and CTT mean scores yield the same conclusions about paradigm-specific forgetting trajectories?
Hypothesis: IRT and CTT should converge (r > 0.70; Cohen's kappa > 0.60), demonstrating robustness of paradigm findings to measurement approach.
Data_Required: IRT theta from RQ 5.3.1. TSVR and purified items from RQ 5.3.1. Raw data: data/cache/dfData.csv. Sample: N=100 x 4 tests x 3 paradigms = 1200 observations.
Analysis_Specification: (0) Load IRT theta, TSVR, purified items from RQ 5.3.1. (1) Compute CTT mean scores per UID x test x paradigm. (2) Pearson correlations per paradigm with Holm-Bonferroni. Report dual p-values (Decision D068). (3) Fit parallel LMMs. (4) Validate assumptions. (5) Compare fixed effects: Cohen's kappa > 0.60. (6) Compare AIC/BIC. (7-8) Prepare scatterplot and trajectory data.
Expected_Output: results/step02_correlations.csv (4 rows); results/step03_irt_lmm_summary.txt; results/step03_ctt_lmm_summary.txt; results/step05_coefficient_comparison.csv; results/step05_agreement_metrics.csv; plots/step07_scatterplot_data.csv; plots/step08_trajectory_data.csv
Success_Criteria: All correlations r > 0.70. Cohen's kappa > 0.60. Agreement >= 80%. Both models converge. Dual p-values present.

Title: If we compute CTT scores using only IRT-retained items (post-purification), do conclusions differ from full-item CTT for paradigms?
Hypothesis: Purified CTT will show higher correlation with IRT theta compared to full CTT for paradigms, demonstrating item purification removes measurement noise.
Data_Required: DERIVED from RQ 5.3.1: purified items, theta scores, TSVR mapping. Raw data: data/cache/dfData.csv. Sample: N=100 x 4 tests = 400 observations.
Analysis_Specification: (0) Load RQ 5.3.1 outputs. (1) Map retained vs removed items by paradigm. (2) Compute Full CTT. (3) Compute Purified CTT. (4) Cronbach's alpha with bootstrap CIs. (5) Correlation analysis with Steiger's z-test. Report dual p-values (Decision D068). (6) Z-standardize. (7) Fit parallel LMMs; compare AIC. (8) Prepare comparison data.
Expected_Output: data/step01_item_mapping.csv; data/step02_ctt_full_scores.csv; data/step03_ctt_purified_scores.csv; data/step04_reliability_assessment.csv; data/step05_correlation_analysis.csv; data/step07_lmm_model_comparison.csv; plots/step08_correlation_comparison_data.csv
Success_Criteria: Item mapping correct. CTT scores in [0,1]. Correlations with dual p-values. All LMMs converge.

Title: What proportion of variance in forgetting rate is between-person vs within-person for each paradigm?
Hypothesis: Substantial between-person variance (ICC > 0.40) exists within each paradigm, with potential paradigm differences reflecting differential trait-like stability.
Data_Required: DERIVED from RQ 5.3.1: best-fitting LMM model. Theta scores. Sample: N=100, 1200 observations (3 paradigms). No new IRT calibration.
Analysis_Specification: (1) Fit paradigm-stratified LMMs with random slopes. (2) Extract variance components per paradigm. (3) Compute ICC per paradigm. (4) Extract individual random effects. (5) Test intercept-slope correlations. (6) Compare ICC across paradigms.
Expected_Output: data/step02_variance_components.csv (15 rows); data/step03_icc_estimates.csv (9 rows); data/step04_random_effects.csv (300 rows); data/step05_paradigm_icc_comparison.csv; plots/step06_paradigm_icc_barplot.png
Success_Criteria: All 3 models converge. ICC in [0,1]. 300 random effects. Dual p-values. Paradigm comparison interpretable.

Title: Can participants be grouped into latent classes based on paradigm-specific forgetting trajectories?
Hypothesis: Exploratory. Expected 2-4 profiles based on 6 clustering variables (intercept + slope per paradigm). Profiles may show paradigm-selective patterns.
Data_Required: DERIVED from RQ 5.3.7: random effects per paradigm. Sample: N=100, 6 clustering variables.
Analysis_Specification: (1) Load random effects from RQ 5.3.7. (2) Standardize. (3) Test K=1-6 with K-means and BIC. (4) Fit final K-means. (5) Characterize clusters by paradigm patterns. (6) Scatter plot matrix.
Expected_Output: data/step01_standardized_features.csv; results/step02_cluster_selection.csv; data/step04_cluster_assignments.csv; results/step05_cluster_characterization.txt; plots/step06_cluster_scatter_matrix.png
Success_Criteria: Random effects loaded. BIC minimum identified. Cluster sizes >= 10%. Paradigm-specific interpretations.

Title: Do easier items show faster forgetting than harder items, and does this differ by paradigm?
Hypothesis: Exploratory. Tests if item difficulty x time interaction differs across Free/Cued/Recognition. Recognition may show strongest difficulty effect (more item-dependent).
Data_Required: Item parameters from RQ 5.3.1. Raw response data. TSVR mapping. Crossed random effects.
Analysis_Specification: (1) Load item parameters and responses. (2) Merge difficulty and paradigm. (3) Center Difficulty_c. (4) Fit: Response ~ Time x Difficulty_c x paradigm + (Time | UID) + (1 | Item). (5) Extract interactions. (6) Plot by paradigm.
Expected_Output: data/step00_item_difficulty_by_paradigm.csv; results/step03_difficulty_paradigm_interaction.csv; plots/step04_difficulty_trajectories_by_paradigm.png
Success_Criteria: Model converged. Paradigm-stratified interactions. Plot: 6 lines.

Title: Does schema congruence (common, congruent, incongruent) affect the trajectory of episodic forgetting over 6 days?
Hypothesis: Congruent items (schema-consistent) show slower forgetting than incongruent items (schema-violating). Common items (schema-neutral) fall between. Expected: significant Congruence x Time interaction.
Data_Required: Source: RQ 5.2.1 data filtered to interactive paradigms (IFR/ICR/IRE). Q-matrix: common (*-i1/*-i2), congruent (*-i3/*-i4), incongruent (*-i5/*-i6). Sample: N=100 x 4 tests = 400 observations. Time: TSVR_hours.
Analysis_Specification: (0) Filter to interactive paradigms, create congruence Q-matrix. (1) IRT Pass 1: 3-factor GRM. (2) Purify (Decision D039). (3) IRT Pass 2. (4) Merge with TSVR, reshape to long. (5) Fit 5 LMMs; select best via AIC. (6) Post-hoc contrasts: Congruent-Common, Incongruent-Common, Bonferroni alpha=0.0167. Report dual p-values (Decision D068). (7) Trajectory data (Decision D069).
Expected_Output: data/step03_theta_scores.csv; results/step05_model_comparison.csv; results/step05_lmm_model_summary.txt; results/step06_post_hoc_contrasts.csv; results/step06_effect_sizes.csv; plots/step07_trajectory_theta_data.csv; plots/step07_trajectory_probability_data.csv
Success_Criteria: IRT convergence. 50-90 items retained. LMM converged. Post-hoc dual p-values. Plot: 12 rows, probability in [0,1].

Title: Is the schema congruence effect driven by differential consolidation (Day 0-1) or later decay (Day 1-6)?
Hypothesis: Congruent items show less forgetting during consolidation window (Day 0-1) compared to incongruent items, as schema-based memory benefits from sleep-dependent consolidation.
Data_Required: DERIVED from RQ 5.4.1: results/ch5/5.4.1/data/step03_theta_scores.csv (400 rows, 7 cols). TSVR from master.xlsx. Sample: N=100, 1200 observations (reshaped). Segments: Early (0-24h), Late (24-168h).
Analysis_Specification: (0) Load RQ 5.4.1 theta, validate. (1) Reshape wide->long, merge TSVR, assign segments, compute Days_within. (2) Fit piecewise LMM: theta ~ Days_within x Segment x Congruence + (1 + Days_within | UID). (3) Extract 6 segment-congruence slopes. (4) Extract 11 hypothesis tests with Bonferroni alpha=0.0033. Report dual p-values (Decision D068). (5) Validate assumptions, run sensitivity analyses. (6) Prepare two-panel plot data.
Expected_Output: data/step00_theta_scores_from_rq5.csv; data/step01_lmm_input_piecewise.csv (1200 rows); data/step02_piecewise_lmm_model.pkl; results/step03_segment_slopes.csv (6 rows); results/step04_hypothesis_tests.csv (11 rows); results/step05_assumption_validation.txt; results/step05_sensitivity_analyses.csv (7 rows); plots/step06_piecewise_early_data.csv; plots/step06_piecewise_late_data.csv
Success_Criteria: Model converged. 6 slopes with valid SE/CI. 11 hypothesis tests with dual p-values. Sensitivity analyses complete. Plot data: correct segment assignments.

Title: Does the effect of age on forgetting rate vary by schema congruence?
Hypothesis: Age x Time effects may be strongest for incongruent items (least schema support for consolidation). 3-way Age x Congruence x Time interaction significant at Bonferroni alpha=0.025.
Data_Required: DERIVED from RQ 5.4.1: theta scores (1200 rows after reshape), TSVR mapping. Age from data/cache/dfData.csv. Sample: N=100, 1200 observations. Transformations: Age_c, log_TSVR.
Analysis_Specification: (0) Load RQ 5.4.1 theta + Age. (1) Merge, center Age, create log_TSVR. (2) Fit LMM with 3-way Age x congruence x Time interactions. (3) Extract 4 three-way terms, Bonferroni alpha=0.025. (4) Congruence-specific age effects at Day 3 with Tukey HSD. Report dual p-values (Decision D068). (5) Plot by age tertiles.
Expected_Output: data/step01_lmm_input.csv; data/step02_lmm_model.pkl; data/step03_interaction_terms.csv; data/step04_age_effects_by_congruence.csv; plots/step05_age_effects_plot_data.csv
Success_Criteria: Model converged. 4 three-way terms. Dual p-values. 3 congruence levels with age effects. Plot complete.

Hypothesis: IRT and CTT should converge (r > 0.70; Cohen's kappa > 0.60), demonstrating robustness of congruence findings to measurement approach.

Title: What proportion of variance in forgetting rate is between-person vs within-person for each congruence level?

Success_Criteria: All 3 models converge. ICC in [0,1]. 300 random effects. Dual p-values. Congruence comparison interpretable.

Hypothesis: Exploratory. Expected 2-4 profiles based on 6 clustering variables. Profiles may show schema-selective patterns (e.g., poor memory for schema-violating items only).
Data_Required: DERIVED from RQ 5.4.6: random effects per congruence. Sample: N=100, 6 clustering variables.
